sideA: El stock de los productos está en los almacenes y cada provincia tiene uno diferente.

sideB.text: Product stock is in the warehouses, and each province has its own specific inventory.
Inventory is managed in warehouses, with different Inventory Organizations for each province.
Stock availability is physical and varies because each province points to a different warehouse.
Product stock is in the warehouses, and each province has a different one.

note:
[Points to] is a useful phrasal verb when describing software configuration or database relationships.

[Varies] means 'is different' or 'changes'.

sideA: Eso es todo por mi parte, gracias.

sideB.text: That's all for me, thanks.
That's everything from my side, thank you.
That's all on my end, thanks.

note:
Use [On my end] or [From my side] to refer to your part of the conversation or task.

~That's all on my side, thanks.~ (Unnatural phrasing: The correct idioms are 'from my side' or 'on my end'.)

sideB.text: Can you take that logic out of there?
Can you extract that logic from there?
Could you move that logic out of that section?

note:
[Take out] or [Extract] are good verbs for refactoring code.

[Logic] refers to business rules or algorithms in the code.

~Can you take that logic out from there?~ (Redundant preposition: Use 'out of there'.)

~Can you take out that logic of there?~ (Incorrect preposition: Use 'out of'.)

sideA: Si necesito más información, como pasos o capturas, le pregunto a quien reportó por Teams de inmediato.

sideB.text: If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the reporter on Teams right away.
If I require further details, such as reproduction steps, I contact the reporter immediately via Teams.
When I need more context, like screenshots, I reach out to the reporter on Teams instantly.
If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the one who reported it on Teams.
If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask who reported it on Teams.

note:
[Reporter] refers to the person who created the ticket/bug report.

[Right away] or [Instantly] emphasizes your responsiveness.

~I ask to who reported it...~ (Incorrect grammar: You 'ask someone', you do not 'ask to someone'.)

sideA: Necesito pedirle los requerimientos al cliente.

sideB.text: I need to ask the client for the requirements.
I have to request the requirements from the client.
I need to get the requirements from the client.

note:
Structure: [Ask someone FOR something].

~Ask the requirements to the client~ is incorrect grammar.

~I need to ask for the requirements to the client~ (Incorrect structure: Use 'ask the client for' or 'ask for ... from the client'.)

sideA: Al hacer checkout, la Cotización (ASO) se convierte en una Orden de Venta real en el módulo de Order Management.

sideB.text: Upon checkout, the Quote (ASO) is converted into an actual Sales Order in the Order Management (OM) module.
The checkout process triggers the conversion of the ASO Quote into a confirmed Sales Order in OM.
Data moves from the ASO module to the Order Management (OM) module when the Quote becomes a Booked Order.
When checking out, the Quote becomes an actual Sales Order.
Upon completing checkout, the Quote turns into a Sales Order.

note:
[Upon checkout] is a formal way to say 'when doing checkout'.

[Triggers the conversion] describes the automatic process started by the user's action.

~Doing checkout...~ (Unnatural grammar: Use 'When checking out' or 'Upon checkout'.)

sideA: Ahora chequeé de nuevo, y ahora sí veo la última versión.

sideB.text: I checked again, and now I do see the latest version.
I just checked again, and I can see the latest version now.
After checking again, the latest version is visible.
I checked it again, and now I see the latest version.

note:
Using [I do see] adds emphasis (affirmative), meaning 'Yes, really, I see it now'.

~...now I see the last version~ (Imprecise: Use 'latest version' for the most recent update. 'Last' implies the final one ever.)

sideA: Nuestro principal medio de comunicación será por chat o llamadas por Teams.

sideB.text: Our main means of communication will be via chat or Teams calls.
We'll communicate mainly through Teams chat or calls.
Our primary contact methods will be Teams chat and calls.
We will mainly use Microsoft Teams for communication.
Our main tool of communication will be Microsoft Teams.

note:
[Via] is a useful preposition meaning 'by way of' (e.g., via chat, via email).

[Through] is also commonly used (e.g., through Teams).

~Our main tool... will be by Microsoft team~ (Correction: 1. The app is called 'Teams' (plural). 2. Don't say 'the tool will be by'. Say: 'Our main tool is Teams' or 'We use Teams'.)

sideA: El campo del registro no se ha actualizado correctamente.

sideB.text: The record field has not been updated correctly.
The field in the record didn't update as expected.
The record field failed to update properly.

note:
[As expected] is standard terminology in bug reports to describe the desired behavior versus the actual behavior.

~The registered field...~ (Incorrect meaning: 'Registered field' implies the field itself is registered. Use 'The record field' or 'The field in the record'.)
